abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Financial Management
            Capacity Building Project (FMCBP) for Lao were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was high, the Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            the FMCBP highlights the experience from initially seeking a
            strong project implementation  unit (PIU) organization
            structure to compensate for low national capacity to deliver
            timely outputs to relying on existing capacity for project
            implementation, perhaps at the expense of expediency. While
            a strong PIU could deliver some outputs on time, more often
            than not its staff had to work within the existing low-level
            capacity environment. This critical factor affected the
            project implementation across the board. The FMCBP shows
            that a strong PIU could be effectively used to focus on
            certain critical areas where strong capacity is needed to
            bring about timely results. But for a capacity building
            project in general, it is beneficial to take into account
            and to work with the country's existing capacity and
            given environment to best support the capacity building
            agenda. Due to the need for intensive supervision, a
            technical assistance project would require adequate funding
            and staffing to be able to address and manage challenges at
            the implementation stage, some of which were unexpected and
            unanticipated. The need for intensive supervision will
            clearly benefit from the continuing and close presence of
            the task manager (TM) and the core project team. The TM, in
            close cooperation with other team members in the field and
            at headquarters, maintained the implementation momentum for
            the project through actively coordinating the
            trouble-shooting activities among Bank staff and government
            officials for all the challenges and bottlenecks facing the project.
